When another night came, the columns changed to
purple streaks, filed across two pontoons pontoon bridges. A glaring
fire wine-tinted the waters of the river. Its rays, shining
upon the moving masses of troops, brought forth here
and there sudden gleams of silver or gold. Upon the
other shore, a dark and mysterious range of hills
was curved against the sky. The insect-voices of the night
sang solomnly.
After this crossing, Fleming ^the youth assured himself that
at any moment they might be suddenly and fear-
fully assaulted from the caves of the lowering
woods. He kept his eyes watchfully upon the darkness.
I But his regiment went unmolested to a camping-
-place and its soldiers selept the brave sleep of wearied
men. In the morning they were routed out with
early energy and hustled mile after mile along
a road a narrow road that led deep into the
forest.
It was during this rapid march that the regiment
lost many of the marks of a new cammand.
The men had begun to count the miles up-
on their fingers. And they grew tired. "Sore feet an'
damned short rations, that's all," said Wilson the loud young soldier. There
was perspiration and grumbling. After a time, they
began to shed their knapsacks. Some tossed them
unconcernedly down; others hid them carefully, as-
serting their plans to return for them at some con-
